Other interesting notes about this crawl, having pored over the 
output logs:

* There were no "internal error" results -- that is, unexpected
  Java exceptions due to buggy code or deep I/O strangeness. 
  My smaller development machine text crawls, on Windows XP, almost 
  always have a handful of these, so the Linux IBM JVM/runtime
  classes seems to exhibit less flakiness than the Sun Windows JVM/
  runtime. 

* 709 problematic discovered URIs were logged. Most of these were
  "mailto"s, which aren't yet being treated separately from other
  URI types, and are especially likely to choke the java.net.URI
  parser. Of the other 183, all appeared to be genuinely illegal
  URIs. In a few cases, we might want to tolerate/patch-up the 
  page author's error to match the toleration/patching that browsers
  do; I'm working on such fixes to our extractor.

- Gordon

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Gordon Mohr" <gojomo@...>
To: <archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Monday, July 14, 2003 11:03 AM
Subject: [archive-crawler] Heritrix 8hosts crawl


> I started a Heritrix crawl of our first 8 test hosts early Sunday 
> morning. 
> 
> Some initial results:
> 
> - In 24 hours, it had successfully downloaded over 79,000 URIs. 
> 
> - Memory footprint was under 400MBs at this time -- indicating 
>   that with a similarly-constrained focused crawl we're likely
>   to be able to crawl 320,000+ URIs before exhausting the current
>   RAM-based structures. 
> 
> - At the end of 24 hours, it was only fetching from two of the
>   sites -- match.com and city.fi -- just as with Mercator and
>   HTTrack towards the end of their runs. 
> 
> - At 24 hours, it encountered a bug that halted its useful
>   fetching: while we're properly expiring IP info, we have
>   no facility for doing a fresh DNS lookup. (The "dns:" URI
>   is considered already-fetched, and thus will not be 
>   fetched again.) So from the 24-hour mark on, the logs show
>   only "unable to fetch because a prerequisite is unavailable"
>   errors. 
> 
> Another bug noted: our timestamp-writing routine is using
> 12-hour based times, so 11:59pm is showing as 1159 rather than 
> 2359, and 12:59am is showing as 1259 rather than 0059.
> 
> The logs and ARCs for comparison against Mercator and HTTrack
> are available on crawl09:/0/crawls/test-gojomo/8hosts/
> 
> - Gordon
> 
>
